rComments: Though he can be difficult to understand, his Socratic method of teaching was highly effective and challenged my intellectual capabilities.  In the one course I took from him, I learned more there than I have in all my university courses combined. He is most concerned about the soul, dignity and destiny of his students, and leading them to Truth.

probably the best professor at u of t. Fair grading, interesting lectures, and an absolutely brilliant individual. I have single handedly learned more in his classes than any other I have taken at U of t. He truly provides an amazing university level experience in every course he teaches.
Condescending, narrow-minded and prone to rambling. If you're not an ardent Christian, you almost definitely won't enjoy this experience.

I found him an engagin lecturer, and although difficult to understand, I found his ideas highly insightful. This is university not high school. He challenges students to flesh out their ideas and doesn't let people get away with sloppy arguments just because they are pc. It seems people can't tolerate him because he thinks differently than they do.

The worst professor. Do not take his class. He gave me a final grade without marking my paper. My mark was posted on ROSI. I went to pick up my paper, and he told me it was not graded yet. He difficult to understand, and lazy as a can be.
Professor Silano is passionate about the material but he is an awful lecturer. I found his marking to be fair and I ended up doing quite well in his course.

Possibly the worst professor I've had here. He lacks clarity and his lectures are erratic. This disorganization carries over to his marking where his comments are void of any relevance and his reasons for deductions are ambiguous at best. If possible avoid.

Trying hard to keep his position visa-ve the strong liberal element that holds power in the C In C program. Has softened his initial Conservative views and in some instances done an about face. Never argue with him or debate him unless you like ridicule. Jews who attend should be prepared for a healthy dose of Middle Ages Catholic Anti-semitism.

Excellent pedagogical method.  Admittedly, his method differs from that of the norm, but he enables his students to think rather than regurgitate.  Answered every question intelligently, and never have I once seen him stumped in the two years that I've been taught by him.  Clearly a brilliant man, though one must expect his lectures to be eccentric
He may be brilliant but he is a poor lecturer.  His lectures lack structure, as if he were talking off the top of his head, and he is inaudible.

If you came to university to have Papacy rammed down your throat, you'll be in heaven. A real mumbler though. Opinionated as hell, in contradiction to established  medieval historians such as R.W. Southern. Doesn't seem particularly bothered by Inquisition, Jew-hating, support for tyranny, etc. Should not be at a university.

In summary "This guy is brilliant - if you don't agree it's because you're an idiot". Well, I did 3.85 last term AND I think he's a useless prof. His lectures are mostly inaudible, those times they're not you wish they were. And lets not even get into his ultra-montane Up With Church approach. I can't believe he is permitted on campus, never mind b

People either love this guy or hate him. Take one week of his classes and you'll know where you fall. He's the kind of prof you love to talk to after class but his lecture style is too loose and he has a bad habit of soliciting answers from the class only to drop the full weight of his intellect on them making them less likely to participate later

This guy has possibly the biggest heart of any prof I have come across. Intelligent and to the point. Tought me how to think critically, logically, and with an open mind. His focus and concentration on what you are saying does not allow you shovel it in his class. He's a fair marker too. I can't say enough good things about this man.
Professor Silano is by far one of the best professors at U of T.  He is incredibly knowledgeable and wise, and challenges his students to think in new ways.

Silano is a very knowledgeable professor that accomodates his students. He is extremely religious and philosophical so try to centre your essays around that. Make an effort to agree with everything he says or you may be penalized. If you pose an argument you better be prepared to defend it because he will tear it up. Other than that, he's flexible

I prefer to say Silano is handsome rather than "hot" b/c I use hot to describe food. Anyway, Silano is simply a brilliant man, who is also very kindhearted. He is a man of admirable faith and especially has a love for his native country. He is so approachable, and tremendously generous, you have no idea. He's very humble for a brilliant man like he

He was a difficult teacher to understand.  His lectures probably would have been very interesting if I didn't have to take notes.  He might be the most intelligent person I have ever met.  He knows everything about the medieval church and canon law.  His over-the-top Italian nationalism was often entertaining, but lectures were very Italy-centered

This guy was very narrow minded.  He disagrees with any idea except his own.  He enjoys putting down others who have a difference of opinion.  I regret ever even signing up for this course.  I can;t believe he is a prof.

Gulio Silano is one of the most brilliant people I've ever met. I doubt there's a moment of the day when he's not actively thinking about some issue of import/interest. As to complaints that there isn't enough "structure" in his classes, that's a sad statement about the students not the teacher, he requires his students to THINK not just memorize

Catechism of the Catholic Church: Professor Silano is a wonderful, kindhearted professor. certainly one of the kindest. He is definitely a deep thinker and is often inaudible. But, I recommend taking his classes; he is what University is about.

Prof. Silano is one of the most challanging profs to rate,simply because he is too brilliant for some students;many do not realize his brillance. He is one of the best profs I've ever had. He made me think at a deeper level like no other prof has. Isn't that the goal of univ edu ? If you like structure, you prob. wont like his course

Very hard to understand what he says because he talks into his ample chest.I dissagree that those not comfortable with a Socratic teaching method cannot learn as has been suggested further down the page.Itis not unreasonable to expect a structured teaching method when that is the norm of our society

The professor has a brilliant mind but it would be helpful if he brought down the intellect to a level in which students could understand him.  It is unfortunate that I did not go to his lectures,  but the notes I took were pointless.  Its too bad becuase he is a brilliant researcher.

He tries to teach the class on a 'deeper' level, but ends up talking about nothing.  Lectures rambled on, and he didn't explain his ideas very coherently.  A disappointing class due to poor professors.

He's harder to understand in the big classroom. In small ones, he's a bit easier. Not the most particular marker I've met, but he is tremendously intelligent. He thinks miles ahead of his students. If you can understand a fraction of what he says, you're already ahead.

As I prepare for the midterm, I've realized how little his lectures seem to make sense and tie into the rest of the course. He babbles on, is easily sidetracked, and is hard to understand. One of the worst profs I have had so far. Thank god there are two other profs for this class

I cannot follow a single lecture this prof gives.  He jumps all over the place, provides no chronological framework, arrives late to class, and is so monotone you have to fight to stay awake.  In a class on European history, he would do well to mention something other than Italian history.
When you come into class with an intelligent well thought outargument and he blows it away with one sentence-how can you not love that!! Brilliant guy-loved all the courses I took with him.

Ridiculous!  I ended up not attending his lectures b/c they were a waste of time as he mumbled his unstructured lectures.  Impossible to listen to unless you enjoy monotone profs. that speak unclearly, and provide useless information.

Professor Silano really knows his stuff. He's the kind of person who I'm sure would be happy to explain anything to his students, which is great since his lectures were geared toward a higher audience than the majority of listeners in HIS240.

Dr. Silano prefers a socratic pedagogical methodology. the people who don't learn anything from his lectures in HIS220 are people who problably can't learn anything at all. brilliant scholar, brilliant professor.
Absolutely no structure to his lectures. Often appeared to be making it up as he went along. Mumbled and babbled, and basically made little sense.
Very smart guy but really difficult to follow his lectures. Everything I learned from this class came from the readings and my teaching assistant.

What a joke of a class.  An example of a professor who i clearly there to just fill in time.  This professor was patheticly unclear and wasted a lot of $1000.00 credits!  Many are upset.  The exam had nothing to do with what he babbled about.
A smart professor, but lectures are hard to follow and often stray from what is expected on the exams.
